questions.text: A patient was diagnosed for Cholelithiasis and underwent cholecystectomy. What would be the diagnosis according to the given image below? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gallbladder polyp

 

Given image shows a Gall bladder specimen revealing numerous polyps.

 

Gall Bladder Polyp

 

Majority are either adenomyomatosis or cholesterol polyps and have no malignant potential.

True adenomatous polyp occurs in 0.3–0.5% of the population. The risk of malignant transformation increases with increasing size of the polyp.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cholesterosis and Option D. Strawberry Gall bladder: The interior of the gallbladder looks something like a strawberry. The yellow specks (submucous aggregations of cholesterol crystals and cholesterol esters) correspond to the seeds of a strawberry.

 

 

Option C. Gall bladder Carcinoma: Gall bladder Carcinoma specimen resemble chronic cholecystitis on gross examination, often with a thickened wall and possibly a mass. However, the image provided does not show the characteristics typically associated with carcinoma, such as a mass or irregular thickening.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gallbladder polyps, as seen in the image, are common and typically benign, with the risk of malignancy increasing with polyp size. Accurate identification is crucial for appropriate management.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 79, 1709

questions.text: A patient presented with weight loss and malabsorption on eating specific food materials. She has been diagnosed with gluten sensitive enteropathy. Which of the following can be the safest food given to her? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rice

 

Gluten-sensitive enteropathy, also known as celiac disease, is an autoimmune disorder where the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine. Gluten is a protein found in wheat, barley, rye, and oats (BROW). To manage celiac disease, patients must adhere to a strict gluten-free diet. Rice is naturally gluten-free and safe for consumption in patients with gluten-sensitive enteropathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maida: Maida is a refined wheat flour, which contains gluten and is not safe for patients with celiac disease.

 

Option B. Semolina: Semolina, also known as sooji, is a wheat product and contains gluten.

 

Option C. Oat cookies: While oats are naturally gluten-free, they are often contaminated with gluten during processing and are not considered safe unless specifically labeled as gluten-free.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The patients of gluten sensitive enteropathy should not be given the gluten rich cereals like BROW (Barley, Rye, Oat and Wheat) cereals or their derivatives like maida, sooji/semolina (as these are wheat products). So, the safest food for such patients would be rice.

choices.text: Seen in 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD
Increases risk of squamous cell carcinoma

questions.text: All are true about Barrett esophagus except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increases risk of squamous cell carcinoma

 

Not squamous cell carcinoma, but esophageal adenocarcinoma is the cancer risk that is increased by Barrett's esophagus.

 

Barrett's esophagus is a premalignant condition.

 

Barrett's epithelium (columnar metaplasia), dysplasia, carcinoma in situ, and esophageal adenocarcinoma develop sequentially from one another.

 

Microscopically, goblet cells are shown to have taken the place of the squamous esophageal epithelium (intestinal metaplasia).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complication of chronic GERD: True, as Barrett’s esophagus commonly develops as a response to the damage from chronic acid reflux.

 

Option B. Seen in 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD: True, as approximately 10% of GERD patients develop Barrett's esophagus.

 

Option D. Intestinal metaplasia: True, and is a defining characteristic of Barrett’s esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barrett’s esophagus increases the risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma due to the transformation of squamous cells to columnar cells, not squamous cell carcinoma.

choices.text: Malignant melanoma
Rosai Dorfman disease

questions.text: A woman who had undergone total knee replacement surgery comes with complaints of knee pain with the loosening of implants. The following histopathological slide was obtained which showed foreign body giant cells along with the appearance highlighted in the image below. What is your diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metallosis

 

The given clinical scenario and image with the said foreign body giant cell point towards a diagnosis of metallosis.

 

Metallosis is an uncommon complication following total joint replacements of high wear joints like hip and knees. It occurs when metallic components in medical implants, specifically joint replacements, abrade against one another. The metal from the prosthesis infiltrates the bone and soft tissue surrounding it resulting in pain or squeaking on weight bearing or loosening of implant. Sometimes it may be asymptomatic with imaging findings (cloud sign or bubble sign). Aspiration reveals dark fluid consisting of metallic debris.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ochronosis: Ochronosis is a metabolic disorder characterized by the deposition of homogentisic acid in connective tissues, leading to pigmentation and arthritis. It is not associated with metallic debris or foreign body giant cells.

 

Option C. Malignant melanoma: Malignant melanoma is a type of skin cancer that would present with different histological findings, such as atypical melanocytes. It does not involve foreign body giant cells or metallic debris.

 

Option D. Rosai-Dorfman disease: This is a rare disorder characterized by massive lymphadenopathy and histiocytosis with distinctive histological features, including the presence of histiocytes that exhibit emperipolesis. It does not involve metallic particles or joint replacements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metallosis is a rare complication of joint replacement surgeries, characterized by the release of metallic debris from implants, leading to a foreign body reaction with the formation of foreign body giant cells and potential loosening of the implant.

choices.text: Stop the blood transfusion and administer epinephrine
Continue the blood transfusion and monitor oxygen saturation
Administer corticosteroids and start oxygen therapy
Investigate for clerical errors in the blood transfusion process

questions.text: A 32-year-old man undergoing chemotherapy for leukemia receives a blood transfusion. Shortly after the transfusion begins, he develops sudden-onset dyspnea, wheezing, and cyanosis. What is the next appropriate step in the management of this patient? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stop the blood transfusion and administer epinephrine

 

Explanation:


The patient's sudden-onset dyspnea, wheezing, and cyanosis shortly after a blood transfusion indicate a severe allergic reaction, possibly an anaphylactic reaction. In such cases, the immediate and appropriate step is to stop the transfusion and administer epinephrine intramuscularly to counteract the life-threatening effects of the reaction. Epinephrine stabilizes mast cells, reduces airway edema, and improves circulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Continuing the blood transfusion despite signs of anaphylaxis is inappropriate and dangerous, as it could worsen the reaction.

 

Option C: Administering corticosteroids may help reduce inflammation in delayed reactions but is not the first-line treatment in acute anaphylaxis. Immediate epinephrine administration is critical.

 

Option D: Investigating clerical errors is important but not the priority during an acute, life-threatening reaction.

 

Educational Objective:


In cases of suspected anaphylactic reactions during blood transfusions, characterized by respiratory distress and systemic signs, the immediate management is to stop the transfusion and administer intramuscular epinephrine to stabilize the patient and prevent further complications.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with complaints of facial puffiness and frothy urine. Given below is the histological image of the condition. What do you think is the diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Membranous nephropathy

 

The image is characteristic of membranous nephropathy. The given hematoxylin and eosin (H&E)-stained image shows uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall. (Intense pink color)

 

 

Membranous nephropathy is a common cause of the nephrotic syndrome in adults. It is characterized by diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall due to the accumulation of electron-dense, Ig-containing deposits along the subepithelial side of the basement membrane.

 

It is a form of chronic immune-complex-mediated disease.

 

Microscopy:

 

  • Light microscopy: The GBM is thickened without cellular proliferation.
  • Immunofluorescence microscopy: granular deposits containing lg and complement along the glomerular basement membrane
  • Electron micrograph: electron-dense subepithelial deposits (epimembranous spikes) and effacement of foot processes of podocytes

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS): FSGS is characterized by segmental scarring of the glomeruli, which is not seen in the provided image. FSGS also typically presents with focal lesions rather than the diffuse thickening observed in membranous nephropathy.

 

Option C. Membranoproliferative nephritis: This condition is characterized by hypercellularity and a thickened, double-contoured glomerular basement membrane, often referred to as "tram-track" appearance, which is different from the thickened, smooth GBM seen in membranous nephropathy.

 

Option D. Dense deposit disease: Also known as Type II membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, this condition is marked by ribbon-like electron-dense deposits within the GBM, which is not consistent with the features of membranous nephropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Membranous nephropathy is characterized by uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall with subepithelial immune deposits, as evidenced by the histological image provided.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cortans pathologic basis of disease, page no. 1766, 1767

choices.text: Involves degranulation of mast cells
Can occur on first exposure
Most commonly caused by NSAIDs

questions.text: True about anaphylactoid reaction are all except: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IgE mediated

 

  • Anaphylactoid reactions are defined as those reactions that produce the same clinical picture with anaphylaxis but are not IgE mediated, occur through a direct nonimmune-mediated release of mediators from mast cells and/or basophils or result from direct complement activation.
  • Unlike the classic anaphylaxis which occurs on re-exposure to the allergen, the anaphylactoid reaction can occur even on the first exposure. The most common agents that can cause an anaphylactoid reaction include NSAIDs and radiocontrast media.

 

According to World allergy organization (WAO) anaphylaxis guidance 2020

 

IgE-mediated anaphylaxis is considered the classic and most frequent mechanism. In this type, anaphylaxis is triggered by the interaction of an allergen (usually a protein) interacting with the allergen-specific IgE/high-affinity receptor (FcεRI) complex expressed on effector cells, predominantly mast cells and basophils. This initiates intracellular signaling resulting in the release of preformed and de novo synthesis of mediators.

 

Non–IgE-mediated anaphylaxis may be immunologic or non-immunologic

 

  • Non-IgE-mediated immunologic mechanisms may involve the activation of pathways such as the complement system (anaphylatoxins, C3a, and C5a), the contact and coagulation system activation or immunoglobulin G (IgG)- mediated anaphylaxis.
  • Non-immunologic mechanisms have been described for some drugs (opioids). Ethanol and physical factors, such as exercise, may be involved in triggering anaphylaxis through mechanisms which are not fully elucidated. Mast cells may be activated through receptors by certain drugs such as neuromuscular blocking agents and fluoroquinolones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Involves degranulation of mast cells: This is true for both anaphylaxis and anaphylactoid reactions, where mast cells release histamine and other mediators, leading to the symptoms.

 

Option C. Can occur on first exposure: This is true for anaphylactoid reactions, as they do not require prior exposure or sensitization to the allergen.

 

Option D. Most commonly caused by NSAIDs: This is true. NSAIDs are a common cause of anaphylactoid reactions, which can occur without prior exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anaphylactoid reactions are not IgE-mediated and can occur on first exposure to the triggering substance, with NSAIDs being one of the common causes.

questions.text:
What is the correct sequence of cellular events of inflammation? (AIIMS MAY 2021)

 

  1. Rolling
  2. Cytokine mediated integrin activation
  3. Adhesion
  4. Migration
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Correct sequence of events during inflammation:

 

  1. Rolling
  2. Cytokine mediated integrin activation
  3. Adhesion
  4. Migration

 

CELLULAR CHANGES DURING INFLAMMATION

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of intravascular cellular events during inflammation involves rolling, cytokine-mediated integrin activation, adhesion, and migration.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 10th edition pg. 78-79

questions.text: Philadelphia chromosome is caused by translocation of which of the following chromosomes? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 22 and 9

 

Explanation:

 

The Philadelphia chromosome, a hallmark genetic abnormality in chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML), is caused by a reciprocal translocation between the long arms of chromosomes 9 and 22, denoted as t (9;22) (q34;q11). This translocation results in the fusion of the BCR gene on chromosome 22 and the ABL1 gene on chromosome 9, creating the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene.

 

The BCR-ABL1 fusion gene encodes a constitutively active tyrosine kinase, which is responsible for the uncontrolled proliferation and survival of myeloid cells in CML. The enhanced tyrosine kinase activity of the BCR-ABL1 fusion protein leads to the development of this malignancy.

 

The specific involvement of the long arms of chromosomes 9 and 22 in the translocation can be denoted as t(9q;22q) or t(9;22)(q34;q11), where 'q' represents the long arm, and '34' and '11' represent the specific bands on the long arms of chromosomes 9 and 22, respectively, where the breakpoints occur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Philadelphia chromosome, the hallmark genetic abnormality in chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML), is caused by a reciprocal translocation between the long arms of chromosomes 9 and 22, denoted as t(9;22)(q34;q11). This translocation creates the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene, which encodes a constitutively active tyrosine kinase responsible for the development of CML.

questions.text: A patient with dyspnea, respiratory distress due to pan-acinar emphysema, and liver dysfunction is due to a likely defect in which of the following? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Alpha 1 anti-trypsin deficiency

 

Alpha 1 anti-trypsin deficiency is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by a deficiency of the alpha 1 anti-trypsin protein, which protects the lungs from neutrophil elastase.

 

This deficiency leads to the development of pan-acinar emphysema, especially in the lower lobes of the lungs, and liver dysfunction, such as cirrhosis, due to the accumulation of abnormal alpha 1 anti-trypsin in hepatocytes.

 

The combination of pulmonary and hepatic manifestations, particularly pan-acinar emphysema, is a hallmark of this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ATP7A gene: Mutations in this gene are associated with Menkes disease, a disorder of copper metabolism, leading to systemic copper deficiency. It does not cause emphysema or liver dysfunction seen in alpha 1 anti-trypsin deficiency.

 

Option B. ATP7B gene: This gene is associated with Wilson's disease, which affects copper metabolism, leading to liver disease and neurological symptoms but not emphysema.

 

Option D. Surfactant defect: Surfactant deficiency typically occurs in preterm infants, leading to respiratory distress syndrome due to immature lung development. It does not cause emphysema or liver dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alpha 1 anti-trypsin deficiency is associated with pan-acinar emphysema and liver dysfunction due to a deficiency of the protective alpha 1 anti-trypsin protein.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, malaise, and flank pain after a recent course of antibiotics for a sore throat. Urinalysis reveals pyuria, hematuria, and WBC casts. There is no eosinophiluria. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Pyelonephritis

 

Explanation:

 

The patient’s symptoms of fever, malaise, flank pain, and the presence of pyuria, hematuria, and WBC casts suggest pyelonephritis, a bacterial infection of the kidney parenchyma. The absence of eosinophiluria excludes tubulointerstitial nephritis in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis: Incorrect. While hematuria and RBC casts are typical of PSGN, it occurs after streptococcal infections and does not present with WBC casts or systemic symptoms like fever and flank pain as prominently as pyelonephritis.

 

Option B. Tubulointerstitial nephritis: Incorrect. Tubulointerstitial nephritis is characterized by eosinophiluria, WBC casts, and a history of drug hypersensitivity. The absence of eosinophiluria makes this less likely.

 

Option D. Lupus nephritis: Incorrect. Lupus nephritis involves immune-mediated glomerular damage, often with RBC casts and significant proteinuria. It typically occurs in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and is not associated with WBC casts without other autoimmune signs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyelonephritis is a bacterial infection of the renal parenchyma and upper urinary tract. Key findings include pyuria, hematuria, and WBC casts, along with systemic symptoms like fever and flank pain. It should be distinguished from other renal conditions based on clinical and laboratory features.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a growth factor promoting proto-oncogene?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TGF-beta

 

Transforming Growth Factor-beta (TGF-beta) does not promote proto-oncogenes. Instead, TGF-beta plays a crucial role in down-regulating the inflammatory response and facilitating wound healing by promoting the deposition of fibrous tissue. TGF-beta acts similarly to interleukin-10, reducing inflammation and aiding in tissue repair. Unlike other growth factors such as TGF-alpha, PDGF, and FGF, which are involved in cell proliferation and can promote proto-oncogenes, TGF-beta primarily functions to control and reduce inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TGF-alpha: Incorrect. TGF-alpha is a growth factor that promotes proto-oncogenes and is involved in cell proliferation.

 

Option B. PDGF: Incorrect. Platelet-Derived Growth Factor (PDGF) is a growth factor that promotes proto-oncogenes and is significant in the pathogenesis of brain tumors and other cell growth processes.

 

Option C. FGF: Incorrect. Fibroblast Growth Factor (FGF) is another growth factor that promotes proto-oncogenes and is involved in various cellular processes, including cell growth and development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TGF-beta is not a growth factor that promotes proto-oncogenes; instead, it is involved in down-regulating the inflammatory response and facilitating wound healing.

choices.text: Bone marrow biopsy with TRAP staining

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presents with progressive weight loss and splenomegaly. His peripheral smear shows the presence of hairy cells. Which of the following additional investigations will you do to confirm the diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bone marrow biopsy with TRAP staining

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation of progressive weight loss, splenomegaly, and peripheral smear findings of hairy cells is suggestive of Hairy Cell Leukemia (HCL). The definitive diagnostic test is a bone marrow biopsy, coupled with Tartrate-Resistant Acid Phosphatase (TRAP) staining, which shows positivity in hairy cells and is a classic hallmark of this disease. TRAP positivity confirms the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Flow cytometry is useful in confirming the immunophenotype of hairy cells (CD11c+, CD25+, CD103+), but it is not the definitive diagnostic test when TRAP staining can provide a direct confirmation.

 

Option C: Cytogenetics can provide additional insights into chromosomal abnormalities but is not required for primary diagnosis.

 

Option D: Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) may identify genetic alterations but is not the primary diagnostic tool for HCL.

 

Educational Objective:


For a patient suspected of having Hairy Cell Leukemia, a bone marrow biopsy with TRAP staining is the gold standard for diagnosis, as it directly identifies the characteristic features of hairy cells.

choices.text: Interstitial cystitis
Polypoid cystitis

questions.text: A patient underwent cystoscopy, which showed multiple yellow-white plaques in the trigone of the bladder. The histopathology image is given below. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Malakoplakia

 

The cystoscopy findings of multiple yellow-white plaques in the bladder trigone and histopathology image showing Michaelis-Gutmann bodies are consistent with malakoplakia.

 

  • Malakoplakia is a rare condition of unknown etiology primarily affecting the urinary bladder. It is likely associated with chronic inflammation and defective phagocytosis by macrophages. It is more commonly observed in immunocompromised patients and transplant recipients.
  • On cystoscopy, malakoplakia appears as multiple yellow-white plaques in the bladder trigone. The lesions are soft, flat, and slightly raised, with sizes ranging from 0.5 to 5 cm.
  • Histopathologically, malakoplakia shows massive accumulation of foamy macrophages, multinucleate giant cells, and lymphocytes.
  • Foamy macrophages contain granular cytoplasm that is PAS-positive.
  • Michaelis-Gutmann bodies, characterized by cytoplasmic laminated concretions of calcium phosphate, are seen within macrophages.
  • Michaelis-Gutmann bodies represent lysosomes filled with partially digested debris of bacteria, resulting from defective phagocytosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interstitial cystitis: Interstitial cystitis is a chronic condition causing bladder pain and frequent, urgent urination. It does not present with yellow-white plaques or Michaelis-Gutmann bodies.

 

Option C. Polypoid cystitis: Polypoid cystitis presents with polypoid or papillary projections in the bladder, often due to chronic irritation, such as long-term catheter use. It does not show the specific histopathological features of malakoplakia.

 

Option D. Acute cystitis: Acute cystitis is an infection of the bladder characterized by symptoms such as dysuria, frequency, and urgency of urination. The cystoscopy findings would typically show an inflamed, red mucosa, not yellow-white plaques.

 

Educational objective:

 

Malakoplakia is characterized by multiple yellow-white plaques in the bladder trigone, as seen on cystoscopy, and histopathological findings of foamy macrophages with PAS-positive cytoplasm and Michaelis-Gutmann bodies. This condition is associated with chronic inflammation and defective phagocytosis, commonly affecting immunocompromised patients.

choices.text: Moderate or regular exercise for 30 min
Pharmacological intervention with proton pump inhibitors

questions.text: Which of the following measures are associated with an increased life span? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreasing calorie intake by 30 percent

 

Decreasing calorie intake by 30 percent will increase lifespan.

 

Caloric restriction reduces the severity of oxidative damage as well as the resulting decline in function. It lowers the steady-state concentrations of oxidative damage products in proteins, DNA, and lipids. This is due to a decrease in mitochondrial superoxide anion and hydrogen peroxide production and an increase in antioxidant production. Caloric restriction slows the rate of energy metabolism overall.

 

Caloric restriction postpones the onset of age-related diseases like cancer (including lymphomas, breast and prostate cancers), nephropathy, and cataracts. Caloric restriction also reduces the onset of diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and the development of autoimmune diseases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Moderate or regular exercise for 30 min: While exercise has numerous health benefits and can improve quality of life and reduce the risk of chronic diseases, it has not been directly linked to the same extent of lifespan extension as caloric restriction in scientific studies.

 

Option B. Decrease stress: Reducing stress can improve health outcomes and prevent stress-related diseases, but specific lifespan extension evidence is less robust compared to caloric restriction.

 

Option D. Pharmacological intervention with proton pump inhibitors: Proton pump inhibitors are used to treat gastrointestinal conditions like acid reflux and ulcers. They are not associated with increased lifespan and may have adverse effects if used long-term.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Caloric restriction, by decreasing calorie intake by 30 percent, is associated with an increased lifespan and the postponement of age-related diseases. It reduces oxidative damage, slows metabolism, and mitigates the onset of various chronic conditions.

questions.text: A patient with lytic lesions on the skull is suspected of a diagnosis of Langerhans cell histiocytosis. Which of the following is a characteristic finding on electron microscopy? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Birbeck granules

 

The presence of Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm is a characteristic finding of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) on electron microscopy.

 

Birbeck granules have a dilated terminal end producing a tennis racket-like appearance. It contains the protein langerin (CD207). It is seen on electron microscopy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Histiocytes: While LCH involves histiocytic cells (specifically Langerhans cells), the mere presence of histiocytes is not specific to LCH. Many other conditions can also involve histiocytes, so this option is too general.

 

Option C. Eosinophils: Eosinophils are often present in LCH lesions, contributing to the inflammatory response, but they are not a characteristic finding on electron microscopy and are not specific to LCH.

 

Option D. Giant cells: Giant cells may be seen in various granulomatous conditions but are not a characteristic finding specific to LCH on electron microscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Birbeck granules on electron microscopy is a characteristic finding in Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH), confirming the diagnosis of this condition.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition Pg 1168

questions.text: A 60-year-old vegetarian patient presented with weakness and reduced work capacity. He had a Hb of 10gm/dl and MCV-110. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Megaloblastic anemia

 

  • Megaloblastic anemia is characterized by the presence of large, abnormal red blood cells (megaloblasts) in the bone marrow. It is often caused by deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folic acid, both crucial for DNA synthesis in the production of red blood cells. The high mean corpuscular volume (MCV-110) indicates that the red blood cells are larger than normal, which is typical in megaloblastic anemia. Being vegetarian, the patient is at a higher risk of vitamin B12 deficiency, commonly seen in diets lacking in animal products.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron deficiency anemia: Typically presents with a low MCV (microcytic anemia), not high, as it indicates smaller than normal red blood cells.

 

Option B. Aplastic anemia: Involves pancytopenia (reduction of all blood cell types) and does not typically present with high MCV.

 

Option D. Thalassemia: Generally presents with a low MCV and affects the production of hemoglobin. It is a genetic disorder rather than related to dietary habits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of anemia with high MCV, especially in vegetarians or those with dietary restrictions, megaloblastic anemia should be considered. Vitamin B12 and folate levels should be assessed to confirm the diagnosis, and dietary intake of these vitamins should be evaluated and corrected if deficient.

questions.text: Endoscopic and barium swallow images of a lesion in the esophagus of a patient are as shown below. What is the expected histopathological finding? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Image 3

 

The shows an esophageal exophytic growth on endoscopy. Barium swallow reveals an apple core appearance in the middle 1/3 of the esophagus suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. The characteristic histopathological finding in this condition are nests of stratified malignant cells and keratin pearls, which are noted in image 3.

 

In contrast to adenocarcinoma, half of squamous cell carcinomas occur in the middle third of the esophagus. Squamous cell carcinoma begins as an in-situ lesion termed squamous dysplasia (this lesion is referred to as intraepithelial neoplasia or carcinoma in situ at other sites). Early lesions appear as small, gray-white, plaque-like thickenings. Over months to years, they grow into tumor masses that may be polypoid or exophytic and protrude into and obstruct the lumen.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus typically occurs in the middle third of the esophagus and is characterized histologically by nests of stratified malignant cells and keratin pearls, as seen in Image 3.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease 8th edition Pg 1472, 1473

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma
Small cell cancer lung
Large cell carcinoma

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented in OPD with hemoptysis. On examination, a hilar mass was noticed. The histopathological image is shown below. Immunohistochemistry revealed that the cells were positive for p40. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Squamous cell carcinoma

 

The given clinical history and the histopathological findings showing keratin pearls are suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma of the lung.

 

Tumor arises in a large bronchus and are prone to massive necrosis and cavitation.

 

The tumor is diagnosed microscopically by identification of either intercellular bridges or keratinization or keratin/squamous pearls.

 

It is positive for p40 and p63 markers.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adenocarcinoma lung: Generally occurs in the peripheral regions of the lung and is often associated with mutations like KRAS, EGFR, or ALK. Immunohistochemical markers like TTF-1 and Napsin-A would be positive, not p40.

 

Option C. Small cell cancer lung: This type is strongly associated with smoking and typically occurs centrally. However, it is identified by markers such as chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56, not p40.

 

Option D. Large cell carcinoma: This is a diagnosis of exclusion, where the tumor lacks the histological characteristics of other types of lung cancers. It is not associated with p40 positivity.

 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Hemophilia A
Hemophilia B
Von Willebrand disease

questions.text: Prolonged bleeding time is seen in? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Von Willebrand disease

 

Von Willebrand disease (VWD) is characterized by prolonged bleeding time due to a qualitative or quantitative deficiency of von Willebrand factor (VWF), a critical protein in platelet adhesion and aggregation processes. Prolonged APTT (Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time) is also seen in this condition because VWF stabilizes factor VIII, an essential clotting factor. The deficiency or dysfunction of VWF thus impacts both primary hemostasis (bleeding time) and secondary hemostasis (APTT).

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Hemophilia A and B. Hemophilia B: These conditions involve deficiencies in clotting factors VIII and IX, respectively, which primarily affect the intrinsic coagulation pathway but not typically the bleeding time.

 

Option D. Hemophilia C: Known as a deficiency in factor XI, this condition also typically affects the intrinsic pathway and APTT but not bleeding time.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prolonged bleeding time and prolonged APTT is seen in Von Willebrand disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is involved in recognition and clearance of necrotic cells? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inflammasome

 

Inflammasomes are involved in the recognition and clearance of necrotic cells.

 

Inflammasomes are large cytosolic multiprotein complexes that assemble in response to detection of infection- or stress-associated stimuli and lead to the activation of caspase-1-mediated inflammatory responses, including cleavage and unconventional secretion of the leaderless proinflammatory cytokines IL-1β and IL-18, and initiation of an inflammatory form of cell death referred to as pyroptosis.

 

Inflammasomes are involved in pyroptosis, a process of programmed cell death distinct from apoptosis and necrosis. This process is dependent on caspases 1, 4, and 5 and is responsible for killing of infected cells. It occurs in the following sequence:

 

  • Activation of inflammasome complex by infected cells
  • This causes activation of caspase-1
  • This results in generation of IL-1, which is responsible for fever, inflammation, leukocyte recruitment.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Toll-like receptors (TLRs): Toll-like receptors are pattern recognition receptors that detect pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) and play a significant role in initiating the innate immune response. However, they are not directly involved in the recognition or clearance of necrotic cells.

 

Option C. P selectin: P selectin is a cell adhesion molecule found on the surface of activated endothelial cells and platelets. It mediates the initial interactions between leukocytes and endothelial cells during inflammation, but it is not involved in the recognition or clearance of necrotic cells.

 

Option D. Manoreceptor: This appears to be a typographical error, possibly meant to refer to the mannose receptor. The mannose receptor is involved in recognizing microbial sugars and is part of the immune system's response to pathogens. However, it is not involved in the clearance of necrotic cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inflammasomes are crucial in the recognition and clearance of necrotic cells by activating caspase-1 and inducing the secretion of pro-inflammatory cytokines, as well as triggering pyroptosis, an inflammatory form of cell death.

questions.text: A woman, 35 years old, arrives with symptoms of skin thickening, weakened muscles, and paleness in the extremities when exposed to cold temperatures. Her ANA and anti-Scl-70 antibody tests yield positive results. Elevated levels of creatinine kinase are observed, and a muscle biopsy reveals perifascicular infiltration. Which antibody is linked to these findings? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anti-PM-Scl antibody

 

The given patient presenting symptoms that indicate diffuse systemic sclerosis and dermatomyositis/polymyositis, is highly probable to have an overlap syndrome [Combinations of three connective tissue diseases, i.e., systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), progressive systemic sclerosis (PSS) and polymyositis (PM) or dermatomyositis (DM)].

 

Anti-PM-Scl antibodies are characteristically found in patients with overlap syndromes, which involve features of systemic sclerosis combined with polymyositis or dermatomyositis. These overlap syndromes involve a combination of autoimmune conditions, often including systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), progressive systemic sclerosis (PSS), and polymyositis (PM) or dermatomyositis (DM).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-U3 RNP: Anti-U3 RNP antibodies are typically associated with systemic sclerosis but can be found in both limited and diffuse forms of the disease. They are not specifically linked to the overlap syndrome seen in this patient.

 

Option B. Anti-centromere antibody: Anti-centromere antibodies are most commonly associated with limited systemic sclerosis (CREST syndrome), not the diffuse form or the overlap syndrome involving myositis.

 

Option D. Anti-Jo-1 antibody: Anti-Jo-1 antibodies are strongly associated with polymyositis and dermatomyositis, particularly with lung involvement, but they are less common than Anti-PM-Scl antibodies in patients with overlap syndromes involving systemic sclerosis and myositis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-PM-Scl antibodies are commonly associated with overlap syndromes involving systemic sclerosis and myositis, making them the likely antibody in patients presenting with features of both conditions.

questions.text: A patient working in a factory presented with lung fibrosis and thickening of pleura. Biopsy was done. Diagnosis from the histopathology picture is? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Asbestosis

 

This clinical scenario and image showing typical asbestos bodies are suggestive of asbestosis.

 

Asbestosis is a type of pneumoconiosis associated with asbestos exposure. The disease-causing capabilities of the different forms of asbestos depend on concentration, size, shape, and solubility. This condition is marked by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis.

 

Grossly, the affected lungs are small and firm with cartilage-like thickening of the pleura

 

 

The sectioned surface shows variable degree of pulmonary fibrosis, especially in the advanced cases may show cystic changes.

 

Histologically, the following changes are observed:

 

  • Non-specific interstitial fibrosis.
  • Presence of characteristic asbestos bodies - asbestos fibres coated with glycoprotein and hemosiderin and appear beaded or dumbbell-shaped. The coating stains positively for Prussian blue reaction.

 

Note: Asbestos exposure is associated with malignant mesothelioma, a rare and aggressive cancer of the pleura.

 

 

 

Microscopic appearance of asbestos body. An asbestos body is an asbestos fibre coated with glycoprotein and hemosiderin giving it beaded or dumbbell – shaped appearance with bulbous ends.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Silicosis: Another type of pneumoconiosis caused by inhalation of silica dust, but it does not produce asbestos bodies.

 

Option C. Tuberculosis: An infectious disease primarily caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, characterized by granulomas and caseating necrosis, not by the presence of asbestos bodies.

 

Option D. Mesothelioma: While asbestos exposure is a risk factor for mesothelioma, the histological appearance in this case is more indicative of asbestosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asbestosis is identified by the presence of characteristic asbestos bodies within the lung tissue, which are asbestos fibers coated with glycoproteins and hemosiderin, and it is commonly associated with asbestos exposure in occupational settings.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1309

choices.text: Parkinson Disease
Alzheimer's disease

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is most commonly associated with Down's syndrome: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alzheimer’s disease

 

Individuals with Down’s syndrome are at a significantly higher risk of developing Alzheimer’s disease, often in their 30s and 40s, due to the presence of three copies of chromosome 21, which contains the APP gene involved in the production of amyloid precursor protein—a key factor in Alzheimer’s pathology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parkinson Disease: Not specifically associated with Down's syndrome.

 

Option C. Schizophrenia: No significant correlation between Down's syndrome and schizophrenia.

 

Option D. Huntington's Disease: No direct association with Down's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conditions most commonly associated with Down's syndrome:

 

  • Congenital heart disease (in about 35% of cases)
  • Gastrointestinal anomalies (in about 10%)
  • Chronic serous otitis media (in >50%)
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Alzheimer's disease (in the 30's and 40's)
  • Epilepsy (in about 10%)
  • Ocular disorders
  • Reduced fertility
  • Reduced life span (Often due to complications like infections)

questions.text: A 14-year-old patient presents with bilateral proptosis. The biopsy from the region shows this pattern. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Schwannoma

 

The given clinical history and biopsy picture is characteristic of schwannoma showing hypercellular areas (Antoni A), including Verocay bodies, as well as looser (hypocellular) areas, myxoid regions (Antoni B).

 

 

 

Schwannomas are well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses that are attached to the nerve but can be separated from it. Tumors form firm, gray masses that may have areas of cystic and xanthomatous change.

 

On microscopic examination tumors show a mixture of two growth patterns:

 

  • In the Antoni A pattern of growth, elongated cells with cytoplasmic processes are arranged in fascicles in areas of moderate to high cellularity and scant stromal matrix; the “nuclear-free zones” of processes that lie between the regions of nuclear palisading are termed Verocay bodies.
  • In the Antoni B pattern of growth, the tumor is less densely cellular (hypocellular) and consists of a loose meshwork of cells, microcysts and myxoid stroma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leiomyoma: Leiomyomas are benign smooth muscle tumors that do not typically present with the histological features observed in the provided image, such as Verocay bodies or the Antoni A/B patterns seen in schwannomas.

 

Option C. Rhabdomyosarcoma: Rhabdomyosarcoma is a malignant tumor of skeletal muscle origin, often characterized by spindle-shaped cells and cross-striations on histology. It lacks the distinctive Antoni A and B patterns seen in schwannomas.

 

Option D. Fibromatosis: Fibromatosis refers to a group of benign fibrous tissue proliferations that are locally aggressive but lack the encapsulated, well-circumscribed nature of schwannomas. The histology of fibromatosis does not show the Antoni A and B patterns or Verocay bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Schwannomas are benign nerve sheath tumors with distinct Antoni A and B growth patterns, including Verocay bodies. These features, along with the clinical presentation, are key to the diagnosis.

 

Clinical presentations: 

 

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page no - 2595

questions.text: A worker in an industry for the last 20 years develops dry cough and chest tightness. He had the following finding in his pulmonary biopsy. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Asbestosis

 

The biopsy image and clinical history suggest a diagnosis of asbestosis. Asbestosis is a lung disease caused by prolonged inhalation of asbestos fibers, commonly seen in workers exposed to construction, shipyard, or insulation industries.

 

The characteristic finding in the biopsy is the presence of asbestos bodies, which appear as beaded or dumbbell-shaped fibers coated with iron-rich proteinaceous material, giving a beaded appearance.

 

 

This is the key diagnostic feature that differentiates asbestosis from other pneumoconioses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Silicosis: Typically occurs in workers exposed to silica dust, such as those in mining, sandblasting, or construction. It is characterized by nodular fibrosis in the upper lobes and does not show the beaded appearance of asbestos fibers on biopsy.

 

Option B. Anthracosis: Also known as coal worker’s pneumoconiosis, this condition results from the inhalation of coal dust. It presents with black lung tissue and anthracotic pigment but lacks the distinct asbestos bodies seen in asbestosis.

 

Option C. Berylliosis: Caused by inhalation of beryllium particles, typically affecting workers in the aerospace, electronics, or manufacturing industries. It presents with non-caseating granulomas on biopsy, not the beaded asbestos fibers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asbestosis is characterized by the presence of asbestos bodies with a beaded or dumbbell appearance on lung biopsy, often seen in workers with long-term exposure to asbestos fibers.

questions.text: Which of the following stains cause brown color to Her 2 neu cells of breast carcinoma as shown in the image? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diamino benzidene

 

  • Diaminobenzidine (DAB) is commonly used as a chromogen in immunohistochemistry. It reacts with the peroxidase enzyme in a substrate solution, producing a brown precipitate that is visible under a microscope, marking the antigen-antibody binding site.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluorescein Isothiocyanate: This is a fluorochrome and not used for color development in traditional histopathological stains, but rather for fluorescence microscopy.

 

Option B. Alkaline Phosphatase: This enzyme can be used in immunohistochemistry, typically resulting in red or blue stains, depending on the substrate used, not brown.

 

Option D. Benzene: This is an organic solvent and not used as a chromogen in histopathology or immunohistochemistry.

 

Educational objective:

 

For staining specific proteins like Her2 in breast carcinoma tissues, diaminobenzidine (DAB) is a preferred chromogen for peroxidase-mediated reactions in immunohistochemistry, yielding a distinct brown coloration which highlights the presence of the target antigen.

questions.text: Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in a patient with the image of chromosome 15 represented here? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans: A) Angelman syndrome

 

Explanation:


The image represents chromosome 15, showing a deletion specifically on the maternal chromosome. Angelman syndrome is caused by the deletion or inactivation of the maternal copy of chromosome 15q11-q13.

 

This genetic disorder is characterized by severe intellectual disability, speech impairment, ataxia, seizures, and a characteristic happy demeanor with frequent smiling and laughter. The primary causes of Angelman syndrome are maternal deletion and paternal uniparental disomy (paternal UPD), where two paternal chromosome copies are active, and the maternal copy is absent or silenced.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prader-Willi syndrome: Prader-Willi syndrome results from a deletion of the paternal chromosome 15q11-q13 or maternal UPD. It presents with hypotonia, hyperphagia leading to obesity, and intellectual disability, which is different from Angelman syndrome.

 

Option C. Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome: Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is caused by epigenetic or genetic alterations involving chromosome 11p15, not chromosome 15. It is characterized by macrosomia, organomegaly, and an increased risk of embryonal tumors.

 

Option D. Edward syndrome: Edward syndrome (Trisomy 18) is caused by an extra chromosome 18 and does not involve deletions on chromosome 15. It presents with intellectual disability, heart defects, and distinct physical anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:


Angelman syndrome is caused by a deletion or inactivation of the maternal chromosome 15q11-q13 or by paternal uniparental disomy. It is characterized by severe intellectual disability, a cheerful demeanor, and motor and speech impairments.

choices.text: NK cells, neutrophils and eosinophils

questions.text: Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) is seen with: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) NK cells, neutrophils and eosinophils

 

Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) is mediated by NK cells, neutrophils and eosinophils (killing certain parasitic worms like helminths via lgE antibodies).

 

In ADCC, cells/ antigens are coated with IgG antibodies. These are killed by effector cells like NK cells and macrophages. These effector cells bind to the target by their receptors for the Fc fragment of IgG and cell lysis proceeds without phagocytosis.

 

 

Role of NK Cells: NK cells are key mediators of ADCC. They express the Fc receptor CD16 (FcγRIII), which specifically recognizes the Fc portion of IgG antibodies bound to target cells. Upon engagement, NK cells degranulate, releasing cytotoxic molecules that induce apoptosis in the target cell.

 

Role of Neutrophils and Eosinophils: Eosinophils are particularly involved in the ADCC response against larger parasites, such as helminths, where they utilize IgE antibodies to recognize and attack these pathogens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) is primarily mediated by NK cells, neutrophils, and eosinophils, which kill target cells coated with antibodies through mechanisms that do not involve phagocytosis.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg no. 356

choices.text: Acquired anomaly may be seen in myelodysplasia
Associated with normal survival of neutrophils

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Pelger-Huet Anomaly is false? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Associated with large platelets.

 

Pelger-Huet anomaly is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by hypo segmented neutrophils with coarse, clumped chromatin, typically appearing as bilobed ("pince-nez" or "spectacle-shaped") nuclei. It is not associated with large platelets. The anomaly affects granulocyte nuclear segmentation but does not impact platelet morphology. Large platelets are more commonly associated with other conditions such as immune thrombocytopenia, Bernard-Soulier syndrome, or May-Hegglin anomaly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inherited trait with hypo segmented neutrophils - This is a true statement. The hereditary form of Pelger-Huet anomaly is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by hypo segmented neutrophils with coarse clumped chromatin and normal neutrophil function.

 

Option B. Acquired anomaly may be seen in myelodysplasia - This is a true statement. Pseudo-Pelger-Huet cells are commonly seen in myelodysplastic syndromes. These cells are one of the characteristic findings of dysgranulopoiesis in MDS.

 

Option C. Associated with normal survival of neutrophils - This is a true statement. Despite the nuclear abnormality, neutrophil function and survival remain normal in hereditary Pelger-Huet anomaly. The condition is generally benign and does not affect the functional capabilities of neutrophils.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pelger-Huet anomaly affects nuclear segmentation of neutrophils but does not impact platelet morphology; the abnormal hypo segmented neutrophils retain normal function and survival time in the hereditary form of the condition.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presented with heartburn and increased salivation. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy was done, and the biopsy result is shown below. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Barrett’s esophagus

 

This image indicates the diagnostic features of Barrett's esophagus. Note the transition between esophageal squamous mucosa and Barrett metaplasia, with abundant metaplastic goblet cells.

 

 

Barrett's esophagus is a complication of chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) characterized by intestinal metaplasia within the esophageal squamous mucosa. It is a premalignant condition that confers an increased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma.

 

Hence, patients diagnosed with Barrett's Esophagus require that periodic endoscopy with biopsy, for detection of dysplasia every 1-2 years to detect dysplasias.

 

The presence of dysplasia is associated with prolonged symptoms, longer segment length, increased patient age, and Caucasian

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Esophagitis: While esophagitis, inflammation of the esophagus, may be seen in GERD, it does not show the characteristic intestinal metaplasia with goblet cells as seen in Barrett's esophagus.

 

Option B. Squamous cell carcinoma: This type of cancer originates from the squamous cells of the esophagus and does not involve the metaplastic changes characteristic of Barrett's esophagus.

 

Option C. Adenocarcinoma: Adenocarcinoma of the esophagus can develop from Barrett's esophagus, but the histological image provided is more consistent with the premalignant stage of Barrett's esophagus rather than adenocarcinoma itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barrett's esophagus is a premalignant condition marked by intestinal metaplasia with goblet cells within the esophageal squamous mucosa, requiring regular surveillance for dysplasia and potential progression to adenocarcinoma.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page No. 1464

questions.text: Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are seen in which condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Infective endocarditis

 

Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are seen in infective endocarditis.

 

The aortic and mitral valves are the most commonly affected, but the right heart valves may also be involved in some cases.

 

Vegetations can be single or multiple, with one or more valves involved. Embolization is common and, due to the presence of virulent organisms in the emboli, can result in septic infarctions or mycotic aneurysms at the site of lodgment.

 

Other Options:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are a hallmark of infective endocarditis, characterized by the presence of bacterial colonies and significant inflammatory response.

 

Subacute Bacterial Endocarditis shows small, friable vegetations.

questions.text: An electron microscopic picture of a cut section of a nerve fiber is given. What is the most commonly affected area in Guillain-Barre syndrome? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1  

 

The myelin sheath is most commonly affected in Guillain barre syndrome which is marked as 1 in the above image.

 

Guillain-Barre syndrome is acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP).

 

Infections with Campylobacter jejuni, cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus, and Mycoplasma pneumoniae, or prior vaccination, have been shown to have a significant epidemiologic association with Guillain-Barré syndrome.

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • CSF: albuminocytologic dissociation (↑ protein with normal WBC count).
  • Nerve conduction studies: slowed conduction, conduction block.

 

Electron microscopy identifies an early effect on myelin sheaths. The cytoplasmic processes of macrophages penetrate the basement membrane of Schwann cells stripping away the myelin sheath from the axon. Ultimately, the remnants of the myelin sheath are engulfed by the macrophages. Remyelination follows the demyelination.

 

Label 2 – Axon:

 

  • This is the axoplasm or the central axon itself.
  • In axonal variants of GBS (such as Acute Motor Axonal Neuropathy, AMAN, and Acute Motor and Sensory Axonal Neuropathy, AMSAN), the axon is directly attacked, usually by antibodies against axonal membrane components (e.g., GM1, GD1a gangliosides).
  • However, these variants are less common than the demyelinating type (AIDP).
  • So while axonal involvement can occur (especially in severe or axonal variants), it is not the most common target.

 

Label 3 – Schwann cell nucleus:

 

  • Schwann cells make and maintain the myelin sheath in the peripheral nervous system.
  • In GBS, the immune system generally attacks the myelin sheath rather than directly killing Schwann cells or their nuclei.
  • Damage to Schwann cells may occur secondarily, but it is not the primary target.

 

Label 4 – Schwann cell cytoplasm:

 

  • Similarly, the Schwann cell cytoplasm (outside the myelin) is not the main target.
  • The immune attack focuses on the compact myelin (label 1).
  • Schwann cells help with remyelination later but are usually not directly destroyed.

questions.text: Which of the following antibodies is diagnostic for mixed connective tissue disease? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. U1-RNP antibody

 

Explanation: 

 

Mixed connective tissue disease is characterized by high titers of antibodies to U1 ribonucleoprotein (U1-RNP). This antibody is considered diagnostic for the condition, which presents with clinical features that overlap with those of SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis. Patients typically present with synovitis of the fingers, Raynaud phenomenon, myositis, and renal involvement, which usually responds well to corticosteroids, at least in the short term.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-nuclear antibody - While anti-nuclear antibodies (ANAs) are present in mixed connective tissue disease, they are not specific for this condition. ANAs are found in many autoimmune diseases including SLE, systemic sclerosis, and Sjögren syndrome, so their presence alone cannot differentiate mixed connective tissue disease from other connective tissue disorders.

 

Option B. SCL-70 antibody - SCL-70 antibody (anti-DNA topoisomerase I) is associated with systemic sclerosis (scleroderma), particularly the diffuse cutaneous form with increased risk of pulmonary fibrosis and peripheral vascular disease. It is not characteristic of mixed connective tissue disease.

 

Option D. Anti-CCP antibody - Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies are highly specific for rheumatoid arthritis. They are not typically found in mixed connective tissue disease and are used to differentiate rheumatoid arthritis from other forms of inflammatory arthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

High titres of antibodies to U1 ribonucleoprotein (U1-RNP) are the serological hallmark and diagnostic marker for mixed connective tissue disease, a condition with overlapping features of several autoimmune disorders including SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis.

questions.text: A middle aged male presented with features of neck swelling, exophthalmos, sweating, tachycardia and tremors. Which of the following is the likely associated finding in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anti thyroid receptor antibody

 

This patient presents with classic signs of hyperthyroidism, including:

 

  • Neck swelling → Goiter
  • Exophthalmos → Bulging eyes
  • Sweating, tachycardia, tremors → Signs of increased sympathetic activity

 

The given history and the picture of the patient suggest a diagnosis of hyperthyroidism the commonest cause of which is Graves’s disease.

 

The most common antibody subtype, known as thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin (TSI), is observed in approximately 90% of patients. TSI binds to the TSH receptor and mimics its actions, stimulating adenyl cyclase and increasing the release of thyroid hormones.

 

  • Anti thyroid stimulating antibody cannot be the answer as such an antibody
  • Since TSI stimulates the gland for the formation of thyroid hormones. 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-TPO antibody: Associated with Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

 

Option B. Anti-thyroglobulin antibody: Also associated with Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

 

Option C. Anti-thyroid stimulating antibody: Incorrect terminology for TSI, which is already covered under anti-thyroid receptor antibody.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Graves' disease is associated with anti-thyroid receptor antibodies (TSI), which stimulate the thyroid gland to produce excess thyroid hormones, leading to hyperthyroidism. The presence of neck swelling, exophthalmos, and other hyperthyroid symptoms strongly suggests this diagnosis.

 

Graves Disease – Key Features:

 

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 1081

choices.text: Transferrin saturation
RBC protoporphyrin
Total iron binding capacity
Serum transferrin receptors

questions.text: In iron deficiency anemia all of the following is increased except? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transferrin saturation

 

Transferrin Saturation: This is the percentage of transferrin (the protein that transports iron in the blood) that is saturated with iron. In iron deficiency anemia, the transferrin saturation is decreased because there is less iron available to bind to transferrin.

 

It is important to note that in a patient with iron deficiency anemia, there is increased TIBC as well as increased RBC Protoporphyrin levels and the number of serum transferrin receptors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RBC protoporphyrin: This is a precursor in the heme synthesis pathway. In iron deficiency anemia, the lack of iron means that protoporphyrin accumulates, as it cannot be converted into heme. Therefore, RBC protoporphyrin levels are increased.

 

Option C. Total iron binding capacity (TIBC): This is a measure of the total capacity of the blood to bind iron with transferrin. In iron deficiency anemia, TIBC is increased as the body produces more transferrin in an attempt to capture more iron from the diet and the body’s stores.

 

Option D. Serum transferrin receptors: These receptors are present on the surface of cells and are involved in the uptake of transferrin-bound iron. In iron deficiency anemia, the number of these receptors increases as the body tries to increase iron uptake from the blood.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Match the following microscopic finding with the type of tumor? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b  

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which gene is not involved in SCID? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) BTK

 

BTK mutation causes X-linked agammaglobulinemia and not SCID (severe combined immunodeficiency).

 

Other Options:

 

Severe combined immunodeficiency is a defect in both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses. In this condition, the following genes are involved:

 

Option B. JAK3: Mutations in the JAK3 gene are associated with an autosomal recessive form of SCID. JAK3 is essential for the signaling pathways of multiple cytokine receptors, including IL-2, IL-4, IL-7, IL-9, IL-15, and IL-21, which are crucial for lymphocyte development and function.

 

Option C.  RAG1: The RAG1 gene, along with RAG2, is crucial for V(D)J recombination, which is necessary for the generation of diverse antigen receptors on B cells and T cells. Mutations in RAG1 can lead to SCID due to the inability to produce functional B and T cells.

 

Option D. IL-7Ra: The IL-7 receptor alpha chain (IL-7Ra) is important for T-cell development. Mutations in IL-7Ra can lead to a T- B+ NK+ form of SCID, where T cells are absent or non-functional, but B cells and natural killer cells are present.

 

Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including:

 

  • Candida albicans
  • Pneumocystis jiroveci
  • Pseudomonas
  • Cytomegalovirus
  • Varicella

 

Educational Objective:

 

SCID is caused by mutations in several different genes

 

  • JAK3
  • RAG1
  • IL-7Ra

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg 438-439

questions.text: Organisms entering via enteric route into our body are countered by which cells of the liver? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kupffer cells

 

Kupffer cells are specialized macrophages of the liver that are responsible for the destruction of bacterial foreign bodies.

 

Pathogenesis

 

Organisms

           ↓

         Enteric Route

           ↓

       Portal Vein

           ↓

           Liver

           ↓

    Kupffer Cells (Liver Macrophages)

           ↓

   Phagocytosis and Destruction

           ↓

 Activation of Immune Response

           ↓

Recruitment of Other Immune Cells

           ↓

  Clearance of Pathogens

           ↓

  Prevention of Dissemination

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dust cells: These are alveolar macrophages found in the lungs.

 

Option C. Ito cells: These cells are concerned with the storage of vitamin A and are located in the liver.

 

Option D. Mesangial cells: These cells are found in the kidneys and support glomerular capillaries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kupffer cells are the liver macrophages responsible for countering organisms entering the body via the enteric route.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient presents with fatigue, glossitis, and a burning sensation in his mouth. Peripheral blood smear reveals macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils. Laboratory studies show normal vitamin B12 levels. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Folate deficiency

 

Explanation:

 

The patient’s symptoms, including fatigue and glossitis, along with the presence of macrocytic anemia (macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils on peripheral smear) and low serum folate levels, strongly suggest folate deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B12 deficiency: Incorrect. Although vitamin B12 deficiency also causes megaloblastic anemia, the absence of neurological symptoms (e.g., paresthesias, ataxia) and normal vitamin B12 levels make this less likely.

 

Option C. Pyridoxine deficiency: Incorrect. Pyridoxine deficiency is associated with sideroblastic anemia, not megaloblastic anemia, and does not involve macrocytes or hypersegmented neutrophils.

 

Option D. Niacin deficiency: Incorrect. Niacin deficiency presents as pellagra (dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia), not megaloblastic anemia or glossitis with macrocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folate deficiency is a common cause of megaloblastic anemia and is characterized by macrocytes, hypersegmented neutrophils, and low serum folate levels. It typically presents with anemia and glossitis but lacks the neurological symptoms associated with vitamin B12 deficiency.

questions.text: What is the content of given vacutainer? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clot activator

 

The plastic tube shown in the given image has a red stopper, hence it contains clot activator

 

Red stopper plastic tubes contain silica as a clot activator.

 

The tubes are inverted five times to initiate the clotting process.

 

Use – Serum Analysis, Serology tests, Blood banks

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Na-EDTA: EDTA is an anticoagulant used in tubes with a lavender stopper for hematological tests such as complete blood counts (CBC).

 

Option B. Trisodium citrate: This anticoagulant is used in light blue stopper tubes, primarily for coagulation studies such as PT and APTT.

 

Option C. Na-heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant used in tubes with a green stopper, commonly for plasma biochemistry tests.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which test evaluates the extrinsic pathway? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PT

 

Prothrombin time (PT) evaluates the extrinsic pathway of coagulation.

 

PT measures the clotting time of plasma in the presence of an optimal concentration of tissue extract (thromboplastin). This indicates the overall efficiency of the extrinsic clotting system.

 

 

Causes of prolonged PT:

 

  • Administration of oral anticoagulant drugs - vitamin K antagonists
  • Liver disease - obstructive jaundice
  • Vitamin K deficiency
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Previously undiagnosed factor VII, X, V or prothrombin deficiency or defect (rare)

 

Activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT) measures the clotting time of plasma after the activation of contact factors and the addition of phospholipid and CaCl2, but without added tissue thromboplastin. It indicates the overall efficiency of the intrinsic pathway.

 

Causes of prolonged APTT:

 

  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Liver disease
  • Massive transfusion with plasma-depleted red blood cells
  • Administration of or contamination with heparin or other anticoagulants
  • A circulating anticoagulant (inhibitor)
  • Deficiency of a coagulation factor other than factor VII
  • Intake of oral anticoagulant drugs
  • Vitamin K deficiency

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. APTT (Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time): APTT evaluates the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade. It measures the time taken for plasma to clot after the activation of contact factors and the addition of phospholipid and calcium, but without tissue thromboplastin. APTT is used to assess the intrinsic pathway involving factors XII, XI, IX, and VIII, as well as the common pathway.

 

Option C. TT (Thrombin Time): TT measures the final step of the coagulation process—conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin after the addition of thrombin. It does not evaluate either the intrinsic or extrinsic pathways specifically but rather the conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin.

 

Option D. Bleeding time: Bleeding time is a test that assesses platelet function and the initial phase of hemostasis but does not evaluate the coagulation pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prothrombin time (PT) evaluates the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade by measuring the time it takes for plasma to clot after the addition of tissue thromboplastin and calcium. It is commonly prolonged in conditions such as vitamin K deficiency, liver disease, and the use of vitamin K antagonists.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic Basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg 232

questions.text: Which of the following is a good prognostic factor for breast cancer patients? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ER+

 

ER+ is a good prognostic factor for breast cancer patients as it is seen with luminal A and B subtypes of the breast cancer. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High Ki67+: High Ki67+ indicates a high proliferative index, which is associated with more aggressive tumors and a poorer prognosis.

 

Option C. BRCA1+: BRCA1 mutation is associated with an increased risk of developing breast and ovarian cancers, and these cancers tend to be more aggressive.

 

Option D. P53+: P53 mutations are associated with a variety of cancers and typically indicate a poorer prognosis due to the loss of normal p53 tumor suppressor function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ER-positive status in breast cancer is a good prognostic factor because it indicates a slower-growing tumor that is likely to respond well to hormone therapy.

 

Why ER⁺ is a Good Prognostic Factor:

 

  1. Slower tumor growth:
    • ER⁺ tumors tend to grow more slowly than ER⁻ tumors.
  2. Better treatment response:
    • ER⁺ cancers respond well to hormonal therapies such as:
    • Tamoxifen
    • Aromatase inhibitors
  3. Lower recurrence risk:
    • Hormone receptor–positive cancers have a lower risk of early recurrence.
  4. Overall survival:
    • Patients with ER⁺ tumors generally have better overall survival.

choices.text: Transfusion reaction
Acute adrenal crisis
Fat embolism

questions.text: A 24-year-old man met with an road traffic accident and was brought to the casualty after 6 hours. His B.P. was 90/60 mm Hg, heart rate was 110/min, and Sp02 was 92%. A blood transfusion was done. After a few hours, the patient is febrile, tachypneic, and starts bleeding from the IV and NG tube sites. His SpO2 levels started falling. What could be the cause? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transfusion reaction

 

Given the clinical scenario the most likely diagnosis is acute hemolytic transfusion reaction causing DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation) resulting in bleeding from IV catheter and nasogastric tube within a few hours of blood transfusion.

 

Acute Hemolytic Transfusion reaction

 

  • Immune-mediated hemolysis
  • Preformed antibodies in recipient lyse donor erythrocytes.
  • Complement-mediated lysis occurs causing intravascular hemolysis and hemoglobinuria.
  • Severe cases, tissue factor released from the lysed erythrocytes may initiate DIC, which is a consumptive coagulopathy with bleeding manifestations.
  • Other complications include shock, acute kidney injury, and sometimes, death.

 

The various blood transfusion reactions according to their time of occurrence are as follows:

 

  • Anaphylactic reaction - Within a few seconds to minutes of the transfusion. Common in selective IgA deficiency patients.
  • Allergic/Urticarial reactions - Within 2-3 hours of transfusion
  • Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR) - Within 24 hours of transfusion
  • Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHT) - Within 6 hours of transfusion
  • Delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction (DHTR) - After 24 hours of transfusion


TRALI vs TACO:

 

 

TRALI: transfusion-related acute lung injury, TACO: Transfusion-associated cardiac overload, CXR: chest X-ray, BNP: B type natriuretic peptide, PAOP: pulmonary artery occluding pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute adrenal crisis: This condition involves sudden adrenal insufficiency, leading to hypotension, shock, and electrolyte imbalances. It would not typically cause the specific symptoms of hemolysis and DIC seen in this case.

 

Option C. Fat embolism: Fat embolism syndrome can occur after long bone fractures, presenting with respiratory distress, neurological symptoms, and petechiae. However, it typically occurs within 24-72 hours after injury and is not directly associated with blood transfusions.

 

Option D. Hemorrhagic shock: Hemorrhagic shock results from significant blood loss, leading to hypotension and tachycardia. While this could be a consideration, the transfusion reaction and subsequent DIC better explain the patient's clinical presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR) can lead to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), characterized by rapid onset of fever, bleeding from multiple sites, and hemolysis shortly after a blood transfusion.

questions.text: Which of the following is the marker of intestinal inflammation? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) fecal lactoferrin

 

Fecal lactoferrin is a highly sensitive and specific marker for detecting intestinal inflammation. It is commonly used as a marker for inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and is useful in differentiating IBD from irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), which does not typically involve inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Procalcitonin: This is an acute-phase reactant produced primarily in the liver and used as a marker for bacterial infections and sepsis, not specifically for intestinal inflammation.

 

Option C. Tissue Transglutaminase: This test is used in the screening for celiac disease, which is an autoimmune disorder affecting the small intestine but not a direct marker of inflammation.

 

Option D. Albumin: Albumin is a protein produced by the liver and is a marker for liver function and nutritional status but not specific for intestinal inflammation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fecal lactoferrin is a highly sensitive and specific marker for detecting intestinal inflammation and is used to diagnose and monitor inflammatory bowel disease.

questions.text:
Under which circumstances is live vaccination not contraindicated? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. DiGeorge syndrome
  2. Wiskott Aldrich Syndrome
  3. Ataxia telangiectasia
  4. Complement deficiency
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 4 only

 

Live vaccinations are generally contraindicated in individuals with certain immunodeficiency disorders because their immune systems may not be able to handle the attenuated (weakened) pathogens in the vaccines, potentially leading to severe infections. However, there are exceptions based on the nature of the immunodeficiency.

 

  • Complement deficiency: This is a condition where components of the complement system (a part of the immune system) are deficient. Complement deficiencies do not affect the cellular immune response significantly, meaning that the risk of adverse effects from live vaccinations is not increased. Therefore, individuals with complement deficiency can receive live vaccines safely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. DiGeorge syndrome: DiGeorge syndrome involves a defect in T-cell production due to thymic hypoplasia. Since T-cells are crucial for mounting an immune response to vaccines, live vaccines are contraindicated.

 

Option C. Ataxia telangiectasia: This is a condition characterized by defects in both the immune system and DNA repair mechanisms. Patients with this condition have a higher risk of developing severe infections from live vaccines, so they are contraindicated.

 

Option D. Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome: This is an X-linked recessive disorder affecting both the immune system and platelet production. Individuals with Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome are at risk for severe infections from live vaccines due to their compromised immune function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Complement deficiency does not pose a contraindication for live vaccination.

 

However, it is important to note that live vaccines should be avoided in individuals with DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome, and Ataxia telangiectasia, because these are immunodeficiency disorders.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female came with early satiety, massive splenomegaly, petechiae, and bleeding gums. Her hemoglobin was 8 gm/dl and TLC was 85,000/mm3. Which of the following is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CML

 

The clinical presentation and laboratory findings are highly suggestive of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML).

 

The patient, a 20-year-old female, presents with early satiety, which can be attributed to the massive splenomegaly. An enlarged spleen can compress the stomach, leading to a feeling of early satiety. Massive splenomegaly is a characteristic feature of CML, resulting from the infiltration of the spleen by leukemic cells.

 

The presence of petechiae and bleeding gums indicates thrombocytopenia, which is a common finding in CML patients. Thrombocytopenia can be caused by the decreased production of platelets due to the crowding out of normal hematopoietic cells by the leukemic cells in the bone marrow.

 

The patient's hemoglobin level of 8 gm/dl suggests anemia, another common finding in CML. Anemia in CML can be due to the ineffective erythropoiesis caused by the abnormal proliferation of myeloid cells.

 

The most striking finding is the markedly elevated total leukocyte count (TLC) of 85,000/mm3, which is highly indicative of CML. In CML, there is a characteristic uncontrolled proliferation of myeloid cells, leading to a significant increase in the white blood cell count.

 

Other Options:
