Option A. ALL (Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia): ALL is more common in pediatric patients and typically presents with hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, and bone tenderness. The extremely high TLC and massive splenomegaly are more suggestive of CML than ALL.

 

Option B. AML (Acute Myelogenous Leukemia): AML can present with gum hyperplasia, the presence of myeloblasts with granular cytoplasm, or Auer rods (rod-shaped or needle-shaped crystals). The chronic nature of the presentation and the massive splenomegaly are more consistent with CML.

 

 

Option D. CLL (Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia): CLL is more common in older adults and typically presents with lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and a high lymphocyte count. The high TLC with myeloid predominance and the absence of significant lymphadenopathy make CML a more likely diagnosis than CLL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) should be strongly suspected in a patient presenting with massive splenomegaly, early satiety, thrombocytopenia, anemia, and a markedly elevated total leukocyte count with myeloid predominance.

 

The presence of the Philadelphia chromosome, resulting from the reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22, is the hallmark genetic abnormality in CML.

questions.text: The single most important long-term limitation of cardiac transplantation is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Allograft arteriopathy

 

The single most important long-term limitation of cardiac transplantation is allograft arteriopathy.

 

Allograft arteriopathy: It is the single most important long-term limitation for cardiac transplantation. It is a late, progressive, diffusely stenosing intimal proliferation in the coronary arteries, leading to ischemic injury. It can lead to silent myocardial infarction since transplant patients have denervated hearts and do not experience angina. Progressive congestive heart failure and sudden cardiac death can also occur.

 

Other Options:

 

Complications following cardiac transplantation:

 

Option A. Allograft rejection: It is the primary concern that requires close surveillance. Both classic cellular rejection and antibody-mediated rejection is recognized. Cellular rejection is characterized by interstitial lymphocytic inflammation, with associated myocyte damage.

 

Option C. Infection: Infection is common in organ transplant recipients. Bacteria and viruses account for more than 80% of infections after transplantation. The most common bacterial infections early after transplantation are nosocomial, caused by infected intravascular catheters or lines, or gram-negative pneumonias.

 

Renal dysfunction- Immunosuppressive therapy with calcineurin inhibitors has improved both graft function and survival in heart transplantation.

 

Option D. Malignancy: Following heart transplantation, malignancy is identified in 3% to 18% of the recipients, with an estimated risk of 1% to 2% per year. It ranks second to coronary vasculopathy as a major cause of mortality, accounting for 10% to 23% of all deaths following heart transplantation. Cutaneous malignancy is the most common type with a predominance of squamous cell carcinoma. Post-transplantation lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD) is a frequently fatal complication, the peak occurrence of PTLD is 3 to 4 months after transplantation. A strong association of PTLD with Epstein-Barr virus has been observed in several series.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allograft arteriopathy is the foremost long-term limitation in cardiac transplantation, causing significant morbidity and mortality through progressive coronary stenosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presented with scrotal swelling and ataxia. Which among the following could likely be a cause? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Non-Hodgkin lymphoma

 

This was an atypical question, which is important only if it is repeated in a subsequent exam.

 

The most likely cause in the following case is Non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) - Diffuse Large B cell lymphoma (DLBCL) type.

 

Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common form of NHL.

 

The median patient age is about 60 years, but DLBCL also occurs in young adults and children.

 

DLBCL commonly presents with enlarged lymph nodes or rapidly growing mass along with B symptoms, which include fever, night sweats, and weight loss. The B symptoms can be seen in 30% of the patients. Bone marrow involvement is more common in indolent disease and can be seen in up to 50% of the cases.

 

About 50% of the patients have extranodal involvement like stomach or gastrointestinal tract (most common primary extranodal site), skin, bones, spinal cord, testicles, among other locations. Renal involvement can be secondary to bulky disease or lymphadenopathy, causing a ureteral obstruction or due to tumor lysis syndrome. DLBCL can also present with symptoms suggestive of superior vena cava syndrome, compression of the airways. The symptoms can be related to the infiltrated organ if the disease spreads beyond the lymphatics in so-called extranodal disease. A variety of paraneoplastic syndromes may also be associated with B cell lymphomas.

 

Metastasis involves the central nervous system (CNS), skin, contralateral testis, and pleura resulting in local complications.

 

Even though ataxia is seen as a paraneoplastic symptom due to cerebellar degeneration in Hodgkin lymphoma, testicular involvement is very rare and so far, only 5 cases have been reported. Hodgkin lymphoma arises in a single node or chain of nodes and spreads first to anatomically contiguous lymphoid tissues. The extranodal presentation is rare. The extranodal disease can occur at any site like lung, liver, bone, and bone marrow is most common if it occurs. The central nervous system and the testis are exceptionally rare sites for Hodgkin's lymphoma. Thus Hodgkin's lymphoma can be ruled out.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glioblastoma multiforme: Most common sites are the frontal and temporal lobes. Extracranial metastases of malignant gliomas are extremely rare due to absence of a lymphatic system in the brain and spinal cord for systemic dissemination, dense dura around intracranial veins and lack of nurturing stroma in other organs.

 

 

Option B. Hodgkin’s Lymphoma: Doesn’t involve the extra nodal sites

 

Option D. Non-seminomatous germ cell tumor: These tumors primarily metastasize to the lungs, liver, CNS, and bone, in order of frequency. Although CNS involvement can occur, it is relatively rare. The combination of scrotal swelling and ataxia is less typical for non-seminomatous germ cell tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL), particularly Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma (DLBCL), is a likely cause of scrotal swelling and ataxia due to its potential for extranodal involvement and associated paraneoplastic syndromes.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presented with a history of intractable diarrhea. Based on the histological image shown below which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Multiple myeloma

 

The given clinical history with Russel bodies on histology points to the diagnosis of multiple myeloma. The image shows Russell bodies which are eosinophilic, large, homogeneous immunoglobulin-containing inclusions usually found in a plasma cell undergoing excessive synthesis of immunoglobulins. Russell bodies (INTRACYTOPLASMIC) are distended endoplasmic reticulum.

 

Multiple myeloma usually presents as destructive plasma cell tumors (plasmacytomas) involving the axial skeleton.

 

Malignant plasma cells have a perinuclear clearing due to a prominent Golgi apparatus and an eccentrically placed nucleus. Relatively normal appearing plasma cells, plasmablasts with vesicular nuclear chromatin and a prominent single nucleolus, or bizarre, multinucleated cells may predominate.

 

Other cytologic variants stem from the dysregulated synthesis and secretion of Ig, which often leads to intracellular accumulation of intact or partially degraded protein.

 

Such variants include –

 

  • Flame cells with fiery red cytoplasm

 

 

  • Mott cells with multiple grapelike cytoplasmic droplets and cells containing a variety of other inclusions, including fibrils, crystalline rods, and globules.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lymphoma: Lymphomas are malignancies of lymphoid cells, and while they can involve plasma cells, the presence of Russell bodies and the clinical history provided is more consistent with multiple myeloma.

 

Option B. Leishmaniasis: Leishmaniasis is a parasitic infection caused by protozoa of the genus Leishmania. It typically does not present with Russell bodies or the plasma cell abnormalities seen in multiple myeloma.

 

Option C. Urate nephropathy: Urate nephropathy involves the deposition of uric acid crystals in the kidneys, leading to kidney damage. This condition does not present with the histological features or clinical history described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Russell bodies in plasma cells, along with a clinical history of intractable diarrhea (suggestive of increased risk of infections due to nonfunctional antibodies), strongly suggests a diagnosis of multiple myeloma, a malignancy characterized by the abnormal proliferation of plasma cells.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease, Page No. 1126

choices.text: β-2 microglobulin
Calcium levels
Serum creatinine

questions.text: Which of the following is a poor prognostic marker of multiple myeloma? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) β-2 microglobulin

 

β-2 microglobulin is a poor prognostic marker of multiple myeloma.

 

Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell neoplasm commonly associated with lytic bone lesions, hypercalcemia, renal failure, and acquired immune abnormalities.

 

  • CRAB criteria for MM
    • Hypercalcemia: serum calcium >11mg/dl
    • renal Insufficiency: serum creatinine >2 mg/dl or creatinine clearance <40 ml/min
    • Anemia: Hgb <10 g/dl
    • Lytic bone lesions

 

 

Poor prognostic factors for multiple myeloma:

 

  • Serum Beta 2-microglobulin - It is the single most powerful predictor
  • Deletion of 17 pITP53 sequences and the translocations t (14;16) and t(14;20)
  • Polyclonal serum Immunoglobulins
  • Elevated lactate dehydrogenase
  • High C-reactive protein
  • Increased plasma cell proliferative activity
  • High degree of bone marrow replacement
  • Presence of plasmablastic morphology
  • Elevated serum soluble receptor for IL6

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcium levels: Elevated calcium levels are part of the CRAB criteria and indicate disease activity, but are not as strong a prognostic marker as β-2 microglobulin.

 

Option C. Serum creatinine: Increased serum creatinine is also part of the CRAB criteria and indicates renal involvement, but it is not the single most powerful predictor.

 

Option D. Protein levels: Protein levels can be elevated due to monoclonal proteins produced by myeloma cells, but again, they are not as powerful a prognostic marker as β-2 microglobulin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

β-2 microglobulin is the single most powerful predictor of poor prognosis in multiple myeloma, reflecting the tumor burden and the rate of disease progression.

choices.text: Metastatic calcification with normal serum Ca²⁺ levels
Metastatic calcification with increased serum Ca²⁺ levels
Dystrophic calcification with normal serum Ca²⁺ levels
Dystrophic calcification with increased serum Ca²⁺ levels

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with cervical lymphadenopathy and fever. The biopsy has revealed granulomatous necrotizing inflammation. Which of the following is the likely finding with this presentation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dystrophic calcification with normal serum Ca²⁺ levels

 

The patient described has a granulomatous necrotizing inflammation, which is highly suggestive of tuberculosis, particularly in regions where tuberculosis is prevalent. Tuberculosis often leads to the formation of caseating granulomas, which can undergo dystrophic calcification.

 

Dystrophic calcification occurs in areas of tissue damage or necrosis, such as caseating granulomas in tuberculosis. This type of calcification is characterized by the deposition of calcium salts in dead or degenerating tissues, and importantly, it occurs despite normal serum calcium levels.

 

In contrast, metastatic calcification occurs in normal tissues and is associated with hypercalcemia, which is not the case here.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metastatic calcification with normal serum Ca²⁺ levels: Metastatic calcification is not associated with normal calcium levels. It is typically associated with elevated serum calcium levels.

 

Option B. Metastatic calcification with increased serum Ca²⁺ levels: While metastatic calcification does occur with increased serum calcium levels, it is not related to granulomatous necrotizing inflammation like that seen in tuberculosis. This is seen in Sarcoidosis, parathyroid adenoma, chronic kidney disease, William syndrome.

 

Option D. Dystrophic calcification with increased serum Ca²⁺ levels: Dystrophic calcification occurs in the context of normal serum calcium levels, not increased levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dystrophic calcification is a common finding in tissues undergoing necrosis, such as in caseating granulomas in tuberculosis, and it occurs with normal serum calcium levels.

questions.text: Match the following blood components with their shelf life:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b

 

Explanation:

 

The shelf life of blood components varies depending on their storage conditions and preservation methods. Here's a detailed explanation of the correct matches:

 

  1. Single donor platelets: Shelf life is 5 days when stored with continuous agitation to prevent clumping. This is essential to maintain the efficacy and viability of the platelets.
  2. Packed RBC: Shelf life is 42 days when stored in a preservative solution containing saline, adenine, glucose, and mannitol (SAGM). This extends the shelf life while maintaining the quality of the red blood cells.
  3. Cryoprecipitate: Shelf life is 1 year when stored at temperatures below -18°C. Cryoprecipitate is used for patients with clotting factor deficiencies, such as hemophilia A and von Willebrand disease.
  4. Granulocytes concentrate: Shelf life is 24 hours. This component contains white blood cells and is used for patients with severe neutropenia, such as those with febrile neutropenia or aplastic anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Single donor platelets have a shelf life of 5 days, packed RBCs 42 days, cryoprecipitate 1 year, and granulocytes concentrate 24 hours.

questions.text: Primary effusion lymphoma is caused by which of the following viruses? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HHV 8

 

Primary effusion lymphoma (PEL) is a rare type of lymphoma that is most commonly associated with human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8), also known as Kaposi sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV). HHV-8 is implicated in several malignancies, including Kaposi sarcoma, Castleman disease, and PEL. PEL typically presents as lymphomatous effusions in body cavities such as the pleural, pericardial, or peritoneal spaces without detectable tumor masses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HIV 1: While HIV infection can predispose individuals to various lymphomas, including PEL, it is not the direct cause. HIV-1 is primarily associated with immunosuppression, which increases susceptibility to HHV-8 and other oncogenic viruses.

 

Option C. HBV (Hepatitis B virus): HBV is associated with hepatocellular carcinoma but not with primary effusion lymphoma.

 

Option D. EBV (Epstein-Barr virus): EBV is associated with several types of lymphomas, including Burkitt lymphoma and Hodgkin lymphoma, but it is not the primary causative agent of PEL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HHV 8 causes Castleman disease, Kaposi sarcoma and primary effusion lymphoma.

choices.text: Deletion of gene

questions.text: A case of complete gonadal dysgenesis was observed in a 46XY individual with female characteristics. The origin of complete gonadal dysgenesis lies in alterations of the SRY gene. What leads to complete gonadal dysgenesis in the SRY gene? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Deletion of gene

 

Complete gonadal dysgenesis in a 46XY individual is typically associated with alterations in the SRY gene, which is crucial for initiating male sex determination. The SRY gene, located on the Y chromosome, directs the development of the gonads into testes. When this gene is deleted, it results in a failure to initiate testis formation, leading to a phenotypically female individual with a 46XY karyotype. In 10-15% of cases of 46XY gonadal dysgenesis, the SRY gene deletion is the underlying cause. This leads to a failure in developing male characteristics and results in complete gonadal dysgenesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Point mutation: Point mutations in the SRY gene can also lead to gonadal dysgenesis, but this accounts for only a small percentage of cases. The mutations typically involve changes in the DNA sequence that alter the function of the SRY protein but do not necessarily delete the gene.

 

Option C. Translocation: Translocation refers to the movement of the SRY gene to another chromosome, which can sometimes lead to sex reversal if the SRY gene is present on an X chromosome in a 46XX individual. However, this is not the primary mechanism for complete gonadal dysgenesis in a 46XY individual.

 

Option D. Inversion: Inversions involve a segment of the chromosome being reversed end to end. This type of chromosomal rearrangement is less commonly associated with gonadal dysgenesis and is not a typical cause of the condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Complete gonadal dysgenesis in a 46XY individual is primarily caused by the deletion of the SRY gene, which leads to a failure in the development of male gonads, resulting in female characteristics.

choices.text: It should be started within 4 hours of receiving it from the blood bank.
It should be completed within 4 hours of receiving from the blood bank.
No such time restraint and can be done anytime.
It should be completed within 6 hours of receiving from the blood bank.

questions.text: What is correct regarding transfusion of the blood received from blood bank? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It should be completed within 4 hours of receiving from the blood bank.

 

Blood received from blood bank should be completely transfused within 4 hours of receiving.

 

Principles of blood administration:

 

  • All blood products should be given through an appropriate blood administration set containing a filter.
  • A careful aseptic technique should be practiced at all times.
  • Vital signs should be documented before and after transfusion and as clinically required. For the first 15 minutes after the infusion has begun, the patient should be kept under close observation to detect any signs of a serious transfusion reaction. If none is observed, the infusion rate may be increased.
  • One unit of red cells is often given in 1 to 4 hours, depending on the amount to be transfused and on the patient's cardiovascular status. Infusion of a unit for longer than 4 hours is not recommended, as there is a risk of bacterial proliferation because the opened unit is at room temperature.
  • No other solution and no medication should be added to or infused through the same tubing as a blood product.
  • Ringer's lactate or other solutions containing calcium must never be added to a blood product because the calcium present leads to coagulation.
  • After the transfusion has been completed, the transfusion tag or record should become part of the patient's chart.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It should be started within 4 hours of receiving it from the blood bank: This option is incorrect as the emphasis is on completing the transfusion within 4 hours, not just starting it.

 

Option C. No such time restraint and can be done anytime: This is incorrect, as there is a specific time frame to prevent bacterial proliferation.

 

Option D. It should be completed within 6 hours of receiving from the blood bank: This option is incorrect; the recommended maximum time for completion is 4 hours.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blood transfusions must be completed within 4 hours of receiving the blood from the blood bank to minimize the risk of bacterial proliferation and ensure patient safety.

choices.text: Lead poisoning
Iron deficiency anemia
Hemolytic anemia

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presented with a history of fatigue and tiredness. On investigation, he was found to have Hb = 9 gm% and MCV =101 FL. Peripheral smear examination showed macrocytic RBC and hyper-segmented neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely etiology? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chronic alcoholism

 

The given findings are suggestive of macrocytic anemia, which can be seen in chronic alcoholics.

 

Peripheral smear showing macrocytic RBCs and hyper-segmented neutrophils are characteristic features of megaloblastic anemia.

 

 

Chronic alcoholics also have deficiency of folic acid due to:

 

  • Folate accumulation in the liver
  • Excessive urinary loss
  • Impaired folate metabolism
  • Chronic alcoholics frequently have insufficient dietary intake.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lead poisoning: Lead poisoning typically causes microcytic anemia rather than macrocytic anemia. Peripheral smear findings in lead poisoning include basophilic stippling of RBCs, not macrocytic RBCs and hyper-segmented neutrophils.

 

Option B. Iron deficiency anemia: Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by microcytic, hypochromic RBCs, which contrasts with the macrocytic RBCs and hyper-segmented neutrophils seen in this patient.

 

Option C. Hemolytic anemia: Hemolytic anemia generally presents with normocytic or slightly macrocytic RBCs, but not to the extent seen in megaloblastic anemia. Additionally, hyper-segmented neutrophils are not a typical feature of hemolytic anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Macrocytic anemia with hyper-segmented neutrophils on a peripheral smear is characteristic of megaloblastic anemia, often due to folate deficiency, which is commonly seen in chronic alcoholics due to impaired folate metabolism and poor dietary intake.

choices.text: Dystrophic with increased serum calcium
Metastatic with increased serum calcium
Dystrophic with normal serum calcium

questions.text: A 58-year-old man died 24 hours after the onset of substernal chest pain radiating to the left arm. On autopsy, an atheromatous plaque was seen obstructing the left anterior descending artery. Which type of calcification is most likely to be seen in this condition? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dystrophic with normal serum calcium

 

Atheromatous plaques show dystrophic calcification in the presence of normal calcium levels in the serum.

 

The deposition of calcium in dead or dying tissues is called dystrophic calcification. Although it occurs in the presence of normal serum calcium, it can be worsened by hypercalcemia.

 

Dystrophic calcification is seen in areas of necrosis of any type -

 

Calcification in dead tissue –

 

  1. Caseous necrosis in tuberculosis is the most common site for dystrophic calcification.
  2. Liquefaction necrosis in chronic abscesses may get calcified.
  3. Fat necrosis following acute pancreatitis or traumatic fat necrosis in the breast results in deposition of calcium soaps.
  4. Gamma-Gandy bodies in chronic venous congestion (CVC. of the spleen is characterized by calcific deposits admixed with hemosiderin on fibrous tissue.
  5. Infarcts may sometimes undergo dystrophic calcification.
  6. Thrombi, especially in the veins, may produce phleboliths.
  7. Hematomas in the vicinity of bones may undergo dystrophic calcification.
  8. Dead parasites like in hydatid cyst, Schistosoma eggs, and cysticercosis are some of the examples showing dystrophic calcification.
  9. Calcification in breast cancer detected by mammography.
  10. Congenital toxoplasmosis involving the central nervous system visualized by calcification in the infant brain.

 

Calcification in degenerated tissues

 

  1. Dense old scars may undergo hyaline degeneration and subsequent calcification.
  2. Atheromatous in the aorta and coronaries frequently undergo calcification.
  3. Mönckeberg’s sclerosis shows calcification in the tunica media of muscular arteries in elderly people
  4. Stroma of tumors such as uterine fibroids, breast cancer, thyroid adenoma, goitre etc. show calcification.
  5. Some tumors show characteristic spherules of calcification called psammoma bodies or calcospherites such as in meningioma, papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary and papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.
  6. Cysts which have been present for a long time may show calcification of their walls e.g. epidermal and pilar cysts.
  7. Calcinosis cutis is a condition of unknown cause in which there are irregular nodular deposits of calcium salts in the skin and subcutaneous tissue.
  8. Senile degenerative changes may be accompanied by dystrophic calcification such as in costal cartilages, tracheal or bronchial cartilages, and pineal gland in the brain etc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dystrophic with increased serum calcium: Dystrophic calcification typically occurs in the setting of normal serum calcium levels. While hypercalcemia can exacerbate dystrophic calcification, it is not a defining feature.

 

Option B. Metastatic with increased serum calcium: Metastatic calcification occurs when calcium salts are deposited in normal tissues as a result of hypercalcemia. This form of calcification is not associated with tissue injury or necrosis and typically affects tissues like the lungs, stomach, kidneys, and blood vessels under conditions of high serum calcium. It does not apply to the situation described, where calcification is occurring in damaged tissue with normal calcium levels.

 

Option D. Metastatic with normal serum calcium: This option is incorrect because metastatic calcification is always associated with hypercalcemia, not normal serum calcium levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg no 83

questions.text: Zellballen pattern is not typically observed in which of the following tumors? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Glioblastoma

 

Explanation: 

 

Zellballen pattern refers to a characteristic histological arrangement seen in paraganglionic tumors where neoplastic cells are arranged in nests or clusters separated by highly vascular fibrous septa. This is a hallmark finding in pheochromocytomas and paragangliomas. Pheochromocytomas are described as being "composed of polygonal to spindle-shaped chromaffin cells and their supporting cells, compartmentalized into small nests by a rich vascular network" - this describes the Zellballen pattern. Paragangliomas occurring at sites like the carotid body share similar features, as they derive from paraganglionic tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pheochromocytoma - This is incorrect because pheochromocytomas do exhibit the Zellballen pattern. Pheochromocytomas are characterized by "polygonal to spindle-shaped chromaffin cells and their supporting cells, compartmentalized into small nests by a rich vascular network," which describes the classic Zellballen arrangement.

 

Option B. Carotid Body Tumor - This is incorrect because carotid body tumors are paragangliomas that occur in the carotid body, a paraganglionic structure. These tumors show the same characteristic Zellballen pattern as pheochromocytomas because they derive from similar neural crest-derived tissue.

 

Option D. Paraganglioma - This is incorrect because these tumours can demonstrate a pattern resembling Zellballen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Zellballen pattern (nest-like arrangement of cells with rich intervascular stroma) is a characteristic histological feature of paraganglionic tumors like pheochromocytoma and carotid body tumors, but not of glioblastoma, which shows pseudopalisading necrosis and microvascular proliferation.

questions.text: Which of the following plasma protein will decrease in acute inflammation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Albumin

 

In the context of acute inflammation, most plasma proteins, known as acute-phase reactants, typically increase due to the influence of cytokines like interleukin-6 (IL-6) and interleukin-1 (IL-1). These are referred to as positive acute-phase reactants.

 

However, there are certain proteins, called negative acute-phase reactants, that decrease during acute inflammation. Albumin is one such protein. The decrease in albumin during inflammation is thought to help conserve amino acids for the production of more essential proteins needed during the inflammatory response. Additionally, lower albumin levels help to reduce blood viscosity and facilitate the movement of immune cells to sites of inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CRP: C-reactive protein (CRP) is a well-known positive acute-phase reactant. Its levels significantly increase during inflammation, making it a common marker for detecting inflammation.

 

Option B. Hepcidin: Hepcidin is another positive acute-phase reactant. It increases during inflammation and plays a role in iron metabolism, often contributing to the anemia seen in chronic disease.

 

Option C. Ferritin: Ferritin, an iron-storage protein, also acts as a positive acute-phase reactant. Its levels rise during inflammation, reflecting increased storage of iron in the body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Negative acute-phase reactants – Albumin, Transferrin, Transthyretin

 

Positive acute-phase reactants - CRP, hepcidin, and ferritin
